Thanks again for the information.

>

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] On the backs of menuki
messages.msgSnippet: The kanji for the tansatsu entry in the glossary are the same as the ones for tanzaku.  Ask Harry about why he read it that way or just stick with tanzaku.
messages.messageBody:
The kanji for the "tansatsu" entry in the glossary are the same as the ones for tanzaku. Ask Harry about why he read it that way or just stick with tanzaku.

And yeah, those menuki are tanzaku-mei.

Jim



Thanks Jim, I got tansatsu from the glossary of the Kodogu book of
Nihotno Koza. The description on those Goto meuni had it as tankazu so I
looked it up and it was as you say paper strip for wtining on. I figured
it would probably carry over into Nihonto.

cheers

Richard


Jim Gilbert wrote:

>Tanzaku mei is the term I'm familiar with. A tanzaku is a type of long, narrow calligraphy paper.
>
>Even Google doesn't get many results with tansatsu, but this reference looks interesting:
>
>http://www.hitachi-metals.co.jp/e/tatara/nnp0109.htm
>
>Maybe it's already well known among sword guys.
>
>Jim
>

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] On the backs of menuki
messages.msgSnippet: Tanzaku mei is the term I m familiar with.  A tanzaku is a type of long, narrow calligraphy paper. Even Google doesn t get many results with tansatsu, but this
messages.messageBody:
Tanzaku mei is the term I'm familiar with. A tanzaku is a type of long, narrow calligraphy paper.

Even Google doesn't get many results with tansatsu, but this reference looks interesting:

http://www.hitachi-metals.co.jp/e/tatara/nnp0109.htm

Maybe it's already well known among sword guys.

Jim



when signed on the little plates of metal. Are these referred to as
Tanzaku, Tansatsu, or are both correct. ?.

Cheers

Rich


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.msgSnippet: when signed on the little plates of metal. Are these referred to as Tanzaku, Tansatsu, or are both correct. ?. Cheers Rich
messages.messageBody:
when signed on the little plates of metal. Are these referred to as
Tanzaku, Tansatsu, or are both correct. ?.

Cheers

Rich

Jim Gilbert wrote:

>Richard,
>It's Mitsukore. He was in the Shichirobei line. Kyo Goto no Kenkyu lists him as the 6th generation and Haynes lists him as the 7th. He was the son of Ryujo. He died September 7th, 1747. He also used the names Mitsusuke, Mitsunobu, Mitsutoshi and Joshin (different shin from the more famous Shirobei sandai).
>
>Your signature shows some differences from the one shown in Kyo Goto no Kenkyu (p. 62), but that's the only example I have for comparison.
>
>Jim
>
>
>
>
>
>


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Goto Mitsufusa or Mitsutsuna
messages.msgSnippet: Richard, It s Mitsukore.  He was in the Shichirobei line.  Kyo Goto no Kenkyu lists him as the 6th generation and Haynes lists him as the 7th.  He was the son
messages.messageBody:
Richard,
It's Mitsukore. He was in the Shichirobei line. Kyo Goto no Kenkyu lists him as the 6th generation and Haynes lists him as the 7th. He was the son of Ryujo. He died September 7th, 1747. He also used the names Mitsusuke, Mitsunobu, Mitsutoshi and Joshin (different shin from the more famous Shirobei sandai).

Your signature shows some differences from the one shown in Kyo Goto no Kenkyu (p. 62), but that's the only example I have for comparison.

Jim



All, does anyone have a listing for a Goto Mitsufusa or Mitsutsuna ?.

Cheers

Richard

http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/personal/goto-menuki-1.jpg

http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/personal/goto-menuki-2.jpg

http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/personal/goto-menuki-3.jpg

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Ume in hitsuana...
messages.msgSnippet: I m not aware of any such change.  I suppose that as the samurai class got squeezed financially, mounts may have been simplified.  If anything the fancier
messages.messageBody:
I'm not aware of any such change. I suppose that as the samurai class got squeezed financially, mounts may have been simplified. If anything the fancier koshirae in the Edo period were more likely to be fully outfitted with kozuka and kogai.

Some of the filled ana that we see were added by collectors after the tsuba were no longer worn. I don't know how many that accounts for.

Jim



Has anyone ever heard any theories on why you see so many tsuba with
ume in their hitsuana? Was there possibly a change in style or
utilization into Edo which eliminated the need for the utensils?
Thanks!



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: Rich T Whats makes the front and back
messages.msgSnippet: If you look closely to either side of the seppadai the small leaf and branch have fine detail that make them the front side of each accordingly.  Also, in
messages.messageBody:
If you look closely to either side of the seppadai the small leaf and
branch have fine detail that make them the front side of each
accordingly. Also, in general the spacing to the left of the seppa
(kozuka) will be a bit larger than to the right (kogai) as would the
size of the hitsuana for them. These traits are all in the right
side photo.

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Rich T Whats makes the front and back
messages.msgSnippet: As Alan has suggested, and I agree totally, it is more about the balance of the design, the way it naturally sits, and feels. I am of course talking about
messages.messageBody:
As Alan has suggested, and I agree totally, it is more about the balance
of the design, the way it naturally sits, and feels. I am of course
talking about perception here. The natural balance of the guard just
looks right on the right.

And as Rich S has correctly pointed out, there are small tagane mei are
are on the right as well.

Cheers

Rich

messages.subject: Rich T 	Whats makes the front and back
messages.msgSnippet: All, looking at this tsuba, I was wondering about the front and back of it. There is no tell tale sign of design, it is for the most part even on both sides.
messages.messageBody:
All, looking at this tsuba, I was wondering about the front and back of
it. There is no tell tale sign of design, it is for the most part even
on both sides. There is no soft metal so the picture is not dominated on
either side. There are no large Tagane on either side so it is hard to
tell which side was mounted as face out.

Any clues in the design ?, as to which side is which ?.

I think it is the image on the right, by the
balance of the images design.

Rich

http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/tsuba_collection/shoami-bamboo.jpg

messages.subject: Ume in hitsuana...
messages.msgSnippet: Has anyone ever heard any theories on why you see so many tsuba with ume in their hitsuana?  Was there possibly a change in style or utilization into Edo which
messages.messageBody:
Has anyone ever heard any theories on why you see so many tsuba with
ume in their hitsuana? Was there possibly a change in style or
utilization into Edo which eliminated the need for the utensils?
Thanks!
